title: 110_s2784
content: The Act may be cited as the Howard M. Metzenbaum "Menu Education and Labeling Act" or the "MEAL Act". Congress acknowledges the strong link between diet and health, with diet-related diseases starting early in life. Increased caloric intake is a key factor contributing to the rise in obesity rates in the United States. Obesity is associated with various health risks and has significant economic costs. Over the past 2 decades, there has been a significant increase in meals prepared or eaten outside the home, with a third of calories and almost half of total food dollars spent on restaurant food. Excess saturated fat intake is a major risk factor for heart disease, the leading cause of death in the US, with significant economic impact totaling $142 billion in healthcare expenditures and lost productivity in 2005. Heart disease is a leading cause of disability among working adults in the United States, with significant economic impact totaling $142 billion in healthcare expenditures and lost productivity in 2005. Increased sodium intake is associated with a higher risk of high blood pressure, which can lead to cardiovascular disease, especially stroke. The Nutrition Labeling and Education Act of 1990 requires food manufacturers to provide nutrition information on packaged foods, but restaurant foods are exempt from these requirements. (6) The Nutrition Labeling and Education Act of 1990 mandates nutrition information on packaged foods, but not on restaurant foods unless a health claim is made; (7) 75% of adults use food labels on packaged foods, leading to healthier diets, and half change their minds about buying a product based on label info; (8) Limited availability of nutrition information makes it hard for consumers to control calorie intake at restaurants; (9) Consumers want nutrition info when ordering food. Consumers desire nutrition information when ordering food at restaurants to make informed decisions. Surgeon General and Secretary of Health recommend increased availability of nutrition information to reduce obesity. Nutrition labeling of standard menu items at chain restaurants is mandated by SEC. 3. Section 403(q)(5) of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act is amended to include regulations for restaurants and retail food establishments with 20 or more locations under the same trade name. In restaurants or retail food establishments part of a chain with 20 or more locations, information on calories, saturated fat, trans fat, and sodium in standard servings must be disclosed on menus. In chain restaurants with 20 or more locations, menu boards must display calorie, saturated fat, trans fat, and sodium content in standard servings. Additionally, adjacent to the food name, calorie information must be provided in a clear and conspicuous manner. In chain restaurants with 20 or more locations, menu boards must display calorie, saturated fat, trans fat, and sodium content in standard servings. The calorie information must be provided in a clear and conspicuous manner, and in writing upon request for prospective purchasers. This requirement does not apply to items not listed on the menu or menu board, such as condiments and other general use items. In self-service facilities like salad bars or buffet lines, restaurants must display calorie information per standard serving next to each food item. This requirement does not apply to items not listed on the menu or menu board, like condiments or daily specials. Retail food establishments can voluntarily provide additional nutrition information that complies with labeling requirements. State or local regulations may also require restaurants to provide nutrition information beyond federal requirements. The Secretary must propose regulations within 1 year and finalize them within 2 years to allow for variations in serving sizes and food preparation in restaurants. The Secretary must propose regulations within 1 year and finalize them within 2 years to implement the clause. If final regulations are not promulgated by the required date, the proposed regulations will become effective as final regulations. The Secretary must propose regulations within 1 year and finalize them within 2 years to implement the clause. If final regulations are not promulgated by the required date, the proposed regulations will become effective as final regulations. The final regulations will be published in the Federal Register. For vending machines operated by businesses with 20 or more machines, a conspicuous sign must be provided near the food items. The vending machine operator must display a sign near the food items disclosing the calorie content. Operators can also provide additional nutrition information voluntarily, as long as it complies with the requirements. State or local regulations regarding nutrition information for vending machines are not precluded by this clause. The Secretary must promulgate regulations within 1 year of enactment for nutrition information requirements in vending machines. Final regulations must be implemented within 2 years. State or local requirements for additional nutrition information are allowed. The Secretary must promulgate final regulations within 2 years of enactment for nutrition information requirements in vending machines. If final regulations are not issued by the required date, proposed regulations will become effective as final regulations.
